title: Why readers think Bill Belichick belonged in the Hall of Fame this year
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Bill Belichick did not receive enough votes for first-ballot induction into the Pro Football Hall of Fame Class of 2026.
93% of more than 450 Boston.com readers believed Belichick deserved Hall of Fame induction this year.
Some readers mentioned Patriots-era scandals and Tom Brady's influence as factors in Belichick's Hall of Fame snub.

title: Which Patriots Super Bowl will you never forget?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Fans are invited to share their most unforgettable New England Patriots Super Bowl moments with Boston.com.
Notable Patriots Super Bowl highlights include Adam Vinatieri's 2002 field goal and Tom Brady's comeback against the Falcons.
Submissions may feature personal traditions or notable plays, contributing to an upcoming Patriots Super Bowl feature.

title: This runner is raising awareness about stroke and heart disease
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Liz Lang, 48, from Jackson, NJ, will run her first Boston Marathon to raise awareness for stroke and heart disease.
Lang's health journey began with a heart arrhythmia diagnosis in 2006, leading to lifestyle changes and advocating for her health.
She fundraises for Tedy’s Team to promote awareness and support research on stroke and heart disease through marathon participation.

title: Once a patient, now a runner: She’s running for Boston Children’s Hospital
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Molly Kokoski, 26, is running the 130th Boston Marathon to raise funds for Boston Children's Hospital.
Kokoski, a former patient with ulcerative colitis, received lifesaving treatment and now lives with an ostomy bag.
She aims to inspire others by demonstrating that an ostomy bag doesn't have to limit one's life achievements.

title: Saks OFF 5th to close Massachusetts stores
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Saks OFF 5th is closing its Assembly Row and Wrentham locations in Massachusetts due to Saks Global's bankruptcy.
Saks Global will shutter most Saks OFF 5th locations to focus on luxury retail while maintaining a few to sell residual inventory.
The bankruptcy stems from heavy debt related to acquiring Neiman Marcus and rising competition, but Saks Global secured $1.75 billion financing.

title: Middleton loses $2 million state grant after failing to comply with MBTA Communities Act
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Middleton lost a $2 million state grant after failing to comply with the MBTA Communities Act zoning rules.
The grant aimed to improve the high-crash intersection of Route 62 and Route 114 in Middleton, identified by MassDOT.
Despite the loss, a 60-unit housing project will proceed without the intended traffic improvements, raising safety concerns.

title: Thermo Fisher to close Franklin site, impacting up to 80 workers
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Thermo Fisher Scientific will close its Franklin facility by end of 2026, affecting up to 80 employees.
The closure aims to boost efficiency, with most work transitioning to other U.S. facilities and staff receiving relocation support.
The company reported a 4% revenue increase to $44.56 billion in 2025, reaffirming commitment to U.S. manufacturing.

title: To audit Legislature, DiZoglio maintains push to hire lawyers funded by GOP candidate
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: State Auditor Diana DiZoglio seeks approval from Attorney General Andrea Campbell to hire outside counsel for a legislative audit.
Republican candidate Mike Minogue offers to fund the lawyers for DiZoglio's audit, raising ethical and legal concerns.
DiZoglio's request for Special Assistant Attorneys General appointments from Campbell remains unanswered; Governor Healey stays neutral.

title: Quincy chef to compete on ‘Top Chef’ Season 23
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Quincy chef Laurence Louie to compete on Season 23 of 'Top Chef' airing March 9 on Bravo.
Louie is the chef-owner of Hong Kong-style cafe Rubato, opened in 2022 in Quincy.
The show filmed in the Carolinas offers a $250,000 prize and features judges Tom Colicchio and Gail Simmons.

title: Zipcar to close Seaport headquarters, cut more than 100 jobs
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Zipcar's Seaport headquarters to close, with 126 layoffs, consolidating operations to New Jersey.
Boston car-sharing services will remain, despite corporate office shutdown, with regional operations continuing locally.
Avis Budget Group acquired Zipcar in 2013, aims for long-term efficiency through consolidation.
